summary.seg: This manuscript, copied in the last quarter of the 16th century, is composed mainly of Greek prayers and hymns. Some of these are drawn from the Horologion (Book of Hours) known as the Thekara, whose compiler, known by the same name, is sometimes identified with the Byzantine scholar Thomas Magistros (c. 1275-c. 1346). Other short texts include the eleven Gospel readings of the Resurrection (eothina), instructions on the recitation of hymns, and a brief narrative in which Thekara answers a spiritual query from another monk named Theodoulos.

Most of the manuscript is the work of a single scribe, the monk Gregorios, who shifted between two distinct styles of writing. It appears to have been produced originally as six distinct physical entities, four of which are substantial and distinguished by their own separate sequences of quire signatures. Two of these begin with brief prayers of invocation in the margin of their first folio, such as might be written by a monk beginning a new piece of work (ff. 117r, 261r).

Of the other two, smaller portions, one is a single brief quire at the beginning of the manuscript, perhaps originally intended as endleaves before content was copied into it by other hands, including calendrical tables. The other consists of two quires at the end, of which the last few folios were left blank by Gregorios, perhaps for the same purpose, but were filled in with additional hymns, attributed to the 9th-century hymnographer Joseph, by another hand.

It therefore seems that Gregorios did not originally envisage the different portions becoming part of a single volume. However, whereas he wrote no colophon at the end of any of the four substantial portions of the manuscript, he did add one at the end of his work in the last, which amounted to the copying of a mere twelve folios. This suggests that when he came to produce this, the decision had already been taken to bind all of the parts together into a single manuscript, and that this brief portion was intended as a supplement to the larger body of content to which it was added.

The manuscript long retained an early modern Greek binding which may well date from its original production, but due to deterioration and damage to the spine, it has been rebound. The components of the old binding are housed alongside it.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers [i-iii] + 1-323 + [iv-vi], in pencil, in Arabic numerals, recto, upper right.
supportDesc.collation: Part I consists of 41 quires; Part II is a single loose leaf inserted into Quire 28: 14, 2-408, 418-1
supportDesc.condition: There is extensive pest damage around the edges of the folios throughout, which has been repaired with Japanese paper. One corner of f. 197 has been torn away.

binding.p: Conservation binding by Cambridge University Library 2021, with card cover.
The former binding, of Greek origin and probably original to the production of the manuscript, has been retained and is housed with the manuscript.
There are four sewing stations prepared with v-notches. The sewing is an unsupported loop-stitch with an S-twist sewing thread.

Greek-style endbands around two cord cores. The primary endbands are made of wound cream threads around one core. The secondary decorative endband creates a chevron pattern on top of the primary and over a thinner upper core. Yellow and red threads have been used to create the decorative chevron. A yellow and blue loop is visible on the headband towards the left board. This loop probably marks the previous location of a page marker now lost.
One transverse continuous plain textile lining covering up to one third of the boards.

Board attachment is bridling, each station including three holes. The three holes create a v-shape configuration. The thread passes from the spine edge to the inner side of the board. The cover obstructs the study of the outer face of the board; however it can be assumed that the thread travels from the inner side of the board to the outer side and then back inside.

Hardwood wooden boards with horizontal grain. The boards have no grooved edges but are shaped at the spine edge both inside and outside of the board. The inside of the board creates a gentle curve to the spine; the outside edge of the board is rounded. Full covering of dark brown tanned skin with butt-mitred turn-ins.
Both boards have the text of prayers written on the inside, in a late 16th or 17-century hand.

There are four holes on the corners of both boards suggesting previous use of furniture. There is a peg on the foredge of the left board towards the bottom corner, and a hole in the upper foredge suggesting the presence of another peg now lost. There are two pairs of holes through the right board near the foredge, matching the peg location. There are remnants of a braided leather strap on the inner face of the right board on the bottom pair of holes.

Blind tooling decoration, with a similar pattern for both boards. Outer single-fillet border with two double-fillet frames enclosed. Three circles at each corner of the two inner frames. A single tool forming two hearts facing is repeated between the second and the third frame, creating a decorative roll. A single floral tool is used at the corners of the inner frame.
The classmark is printed on two modern paper labels stuck at the head and tail of the spine.
binding.condition: Much of the leather covering material has been lost from the spine and the lower outer corner of both boards and there is cracking of the remaining leather on the spine. There is pest damage to both boards, and a significant amount of wood has been lost from the lower outer corner of the left board.

provenance.p: Possibly owned by a monastery of the Taxiarches in Zagora (the name of a number of different places), mentioned in a note on f. 3v.
Owned by C. J. Cummings Cummings, C. J. of Volos.

history.acquisition: Bought by Cambridge University Library from Cummings in 1891 through H. C. Rae Rae, H. C. of Liverpool, along with MSS Add. 3046-3047, 3049-3053.

recordHist.source: Description draws upon unpublished notes by Patricia E. Easterling. Description of binding draws upon unpublished description prepared (2020) by Samuel Foley and Cecilia Diminuco, Dept of Conservation and Collection Care, Cambridge University Library.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

support.material: ff. 1-4 Western paper, folded in quarto. No surviving watermarks.
ff. 5-196 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Anchor ( c. 78 42 ) in the gutter, comparable but not identical to MoÅ¡in 2511. This example is dated to 1590-1600.
ff. ff. 197-198, 203-204, 213-230, 235-252 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Anchor ( c. 63 37 ) in the gutter, similar to MoÅ¡in 1678. This example is dated to 1575-1585.
ff. 199-202, 205-212, 231-234 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Anchor ( c. 68 41 ) in the gutter, similar to MoÅ¡in 1710. This example is dated to 1570-1585.
ff. 253-260 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Anchor ( c. 70 42 ) in the gutter, similar to MoÅ¡in 2455. This example is dated to c. 1590.
ff. 261-292, 301-308 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Anchor ( c. 65 40 ) in the gutter.
ff. 293-300 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Anchor ( c. 67 40 ) in the gutter, similar to MoÅ¡in 2513. This example is dated to 1590-1600.
ff. 309-323 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Anchor ( c. 75 40 ) in the gutter, comparable but not identical to MoÅ¡in 2511. This example is dated to 1590-1600.

collation.p: The manuscript consists of 41 quires, of which one is a binion and the rest are quaternia.

list.item: Quire 418-1 ff. 317-323 The last folio has been lost, with loss of text

collation.signatures: There are quire signatures in Greek numerals, in black ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, upper right, in a sequence running from Quire 2, the first original quire, to Quire 15 (ff. 5-116). Some have been lost to cropping. They survive on Quires 5, 7-15 (Î´Í´, ÏÍ´-Î¹Î´Í´).

A second sequence of quire signatures in Greek numerals, in black ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, upper right, beginning again from the number 1, runs from Quire 16 to Quire 25 (ff. 117-196). They survive on Quires 16-25 (Î±Í´-Î¹Í´).

A third sequence of quire signatures in Greek numerals, in black ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, upper right, beginning again from the number 1, runs from Quire 26 to Quire 33 (ff. 197-260). Some have been wholly or partially lost to damage or cropping. They survive in whole or in part on Quires 27-32 (Î²Í´-Î¶Í´).

A fourth sequence of quire signatures in Greek numerals, in black ink, on the first folio of each quire, recto, upper right, beginning again from the number 1, runs from Quire 34 onward (from f. 261 until at least f. 308). They survive in whole or in part on Quires 34-39 (Î±Í´-ÏÍ´). It is unclear whether Quires 40-41 ever had quires in this sequence. They could have been lost to cropping, but the crosses that usually appear on the first folio of each quire are also absent from these two.

A cross has been marked on the first folio of each quire, recto, upper centre, on all quires except Quires 17 and 40-41, in black ink except on Quire 16, where it is in red ink. The cross on Quire 26 appears on the second folio, which is the first of this quire to bear any writing (f. 198r).

layoutDesc.layout: f. 1r A single column of 13 lines. 95 70
f. 1v A single column of 14 lines. 110 100
ff. 5r-320v A single column of 18 lines. 135 85
ff. 321r-323v A single column of 20 lines. 138 85

handNote.p: f. 1r was copied by Hand A, in mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink, with modest variation in letter size.
Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is accentuation of all nomina sacra.
The modern eta, modern nu, sigma telikon and loop epsilon are present.
A rubric has been added in the same style in red ink.
f. 1v was copied by Hand B in mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink, with moderate variation in letter size.
Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is accentuation of all nomina sacra.
The modern eta, modern nu and sigma telikon are present.
Punctuation used includes the middle point and full stop.
Headings were written in the same style in red ink.

ff. 5r-214v, 215r-320v were copied by Gregorios (Hand C) (RGK I 88). The main text of ff. 5r-111v, 117r-192r, line 7, ff. 198r-214v and 215r-320v and the headings of ff. 198r-214v and 215r-320v were written in a calligraphic Hodegon-style mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink, with significant variation in letter size, especially in the top line of text. The same hand wrote ff. 112r-116v, f. 192r, line 8-f. 196r and the headings to ff. 5r-196r in a different mixed minuscule style.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. Use of the double dot is functional only and there is accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters and breathings. Horizontal strokes appear above proper names.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas and full stop.
On f. 138v an enlarged majuscule gamma in the top line of text has been designed in the form of a bird's head, with red infill.
ff. 321r-323v were copied by Hand D in mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra.
The modern eta, modern nu, sigma telikon and loop epsilon are present.
Punctuation used includes the midle and upper points, lower and middle commas and full stop.
Headings were written in the same style in red ink.

physDesc.musicNotation: The text on ff. 25v-31r, 48v-53v, 87r-87v, 112r-116v, 186v-187r, 261r-308v and 321r-323v is accompanied by theta notation.

decoDesc.decoNote: The beginnings of some texts are preceded by narrow headpieces in black ink (e.g. ff. 5r, 25v, 117r, 140r) or outlined in black ink with red infill (e.g. f. 176v).

Most texts and sections begin with minor initials in red ink. Some begin with a somewhat larger and more elaborate initial; that on f. 11v is in red and black ink, incorporating a blessing hand, while that on f. 75r incorporates vegetative forms.
Some sections begin with minor initials in black ink.

The transitions between some texts are marked by line-fillers in black ink, in red ink or outlined in black ink with red infill (e.g. ff. 48r, 81v). Those on f. 40r, 184r incorporate zoomorphic forms.
The beginnings of some texts are preceded by simple vignettes in black ink (e.g. ff. 57r, 172r).
The end of the text on f. 260r is followed by a piece of ornament in red ink, incorporating a cross.

additions.p: The original scribe has added various marginal annotations for guidance in red ink, and prayers of invocation on ff. 117r and 261r.
There are occasional marginal annotations in Greek by later hands (e.g. ff. 153v, 188r, 212v-213r).

On f. 3v is a note in Greek in an 18th or 19th-century hand, referring to a monastery of the Taxiarches in Zagora: á¼ÏÏÎµÏÎµÏÎ¯ÏÎ¸Îµ ÏÎ±Ï ÎµÎ¼Î¿Ï Îµá¼°Ï ÏÎ¿á¿¦ á¼°ÎµÏÎ¿á¿¦ Î¼Î¿Î½Î±ÏÏÎ·ÏÎ¯Î¿Ï ÏÎ¿á¿¦ Î¤Î±Î¾Î¹á¼ÏÏÎ¿Ï Îµá¼°Ï ÎÎ±Î³Î¿Ïá¾¶. There are a few pen-trials in Greek.
Some crude drawings of pieces of ornament have been added in the margin on f. 139r. These include a manicule, but it probably belongs to this doodling and does not serve a functional purpose.

origin.p: The main body of the manuscript, ff. 5r-320v was copied by the monk Gregorios Gregorios, monk , as indicated by his colophon on f. 320v, probably in the last quarter of the 16th century, as indicated by the combination of watermarks. This would be consistent with the style of script.

The manuscript contains four successive sequences of quire signatures, while no items of content run across more than one such sequence and the same type of paper is shared only between the first two. This indicates that these portions were originally produced as separate entities. The last two quires, which lack signatures or the crosses marked at the beginning of most of the other quires, whose content is similarly distinct and which were written in a different ink from the preceding quires, probably constitute another such entity. Two portions also begin with prayers of invocation in the margin, suggesting the beginning of a new piece of work (ff. 117r and 261r). However, the fact that all of the four sections with signatures, and the first quire and part of the second quire at the end of the manuscript, were copied by the same scribe in the same format, and that he wrote a single colophon at the end of the last and briefest of the sections he copied, suggests that they were combined into a single volume at an early date. The presence of the colophon suggests that they were intended for this purpose before they left the scribe's possession.

The first quire (ff. 1-4), shorter than the rest, not included in the first quire sequence, partly blank, and copied by different hands in a style suggesting a similar date to the work of Gregorios, was probably originally intended as endleaves. The last three folios of the last quire (ff. 321-323), following the colophon and copied by another hand of similar date, may have been originally left blank and intended for a similar purpose, before having additional content added at some point after the manuscript's completion.

msItem.title: Prayer

support.material: f. 214*r Western paper with no surviving watermark.

collation.p: This part consists of a single slip of paper inserted loose between ff. 214v and 215r.

handNote.p: This slip of paper was written by Hand E, in mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink, with modest variation in letter size.
Breathings are round and mute iota is absent.
The modern eta, modern nu and sigma telikon are present.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points.

history.origin: The text on this slip of paper was probably written in the 17th or 18th century, as suggested by the style of script.
